sections.title: Being Real
sections.preview_public_html: Being realistic about your retirement expectations is the first essential step in financial planning. It involves setting achievable goals and understanding the financial implications of those goals. In a partnership, both individuals must agree on their retirement expectations. Unrealistic plans are often doomed to fail from the start. This section explores how to align your retirement goals with your financial reality.
sections.section_public_html:
Being Realistic About Retirement

For many, retirement confidence is high, but the reality can be quite different. Historically, studies have shown a disconnect between workers’ expectations and retirees’ experiences, especially concerning working for pay after retirement and calculating savings needs. This overview will help you bridge that gap by using data-driven insights to ground your financial plans in reality.

sub_objectives.title: Why Keep a Budget?
sub_objectives.teaser_public: A realistic budget is a cornerstone of cash flow analysis and is crucial for making critical financial decisions.

sections.title: Understanding Inflation
sections.preview_public_html: Money's purchasing power erodes over time due to inflation. This section introduces key metrics like the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and explains why a standard 3% inflation rate may not be sufficient for all of your retirement expenses. You will learn how to customize your inflation assumptions to create a more accurate and sustainable financial plan.
sections.section_public_html:
Understanding Inflation and Your Retirement Plan

While the Consumer Price Index (CPI) provides a benchmark for the cost of living, it may not perfectly reflect regional price variations or specific expenses like medical costs and education. A prudent approach is to use a standard inflation rate as a starting point but be prepared to customize it for different areas of your budget. This section provides an in-depth look at how various economic factors can affect your purchasing power and offers strategies to stay ahead.

sub_objectives.title: What's the CPI?
sub_objectives.teaser_public: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is a widely used measure of inflation that tracks the change in prices of a basket of consumer goods and services.
